Well, tariffs, do you want to talk about tariffs, Nazir?

Sure. I think most of the market is already there has been a lot of information put out. We put a tariff revision in place in September of last year, which was the first major adjustment we did in about three years. I think what was curious in the market that we saw activity from both Glo as well as EMT who came in with fairly aggressive price reduction in December.

And I use the word curious simply because it makes the sort of key value month throughout the year. So, it does beg a few questions in terms of the overall strategy. I think what that has done is forced us to react as well as I think you've seen a reaction from Airtel as well. And we've gone out with a new value proposition that was introduced early in February.

The early signs are promising. I think one of the key questions that we still need to understand through analysis as you go forward is the impact on elasticity and whether it's still driving in a meaningful revenue growth and has an impact on MOUs. I think we need to go through probably a full quarter or two before we get a proper sense of how the market's going to evolve.
Okay.

Hello, Yann Low from At Focus Securities Securities. My question revolves around infrastructure leasing. You've already had a relationship with American Tower in Ghana, can you just elaborate if you will continue with this relationship through other African operations or would you also consider other vendors such as Eaton Tower or Helios Towers?

Yeah. I think that the whole issue of leasing is really one that we started off and I'll let Sifiso add his view going forward. But the idea really was to first of all unlock the value in those towers. There are many permutations in which we could have adopted that. We could have followed quite a number of ways of really unlocking that value. But we started off on a process that effectively resulted in us ending up with ATC. And we said we're going to work with them strategically on it, starting with Ghana on a pilot project. And we will probably do a number of countries with them.

I don't think that therefore that would mean that we're not going to do any work anywhere ever with other tower managers, so to speak, but it will vary from country to country and with the circumstances. So, I think that was the gist of your question, the gist of your question is will every single thing be ATC and nobody else. The answer is no. But we are saying we've started a strategic relationship with them, and of course we need to get to some sort of scale that is meaningful with them. But part of the process will always be evaluating the situation and talking to other tower vendors.
[Question Inaudible]
It just depends. I mean we are going to take a pace. Sifiso do you want to answer the question?

Yeah, I mean that's very much work in progress. The issue about going with ATC was that we did make a decision that we really needed a very well experienced and knowledgeable partner because the running of this infrastructure is critical for our business. And as Phuthuma says, yes, if we find another partner in for other operations, we would consider this, yes.
Okay.

Good morning. Jonathan Kennedy-Good from Standard Bank Securities. Just I wonder if you can comment a little on the strategic rationale for the introduction of the International Board given the success that's been evident over the last while under the current management structures. And then also just on, you've done very well in terms of maintaining absolute EBITDA given declines in interconnect rates particularly in South Africa, do you think or could you give us a sense of where, how much EBITDA could fall off in the coming year, if on-net traffic doesn't move higher?

Okay. Let me try and answer the first question and then Nazir, you may well want to answer the second question on, if MTN are, what do you think that the EBITDA we've got from the MTN, if that disappears, what would EBITDA fall to.

Look, I think on the first question really, as we indicated in the release that we gave. This is an evaluation and it's an also I guess work-in-progress in the sense that we outlined a number of issues. I think the first one is to say as we always say, what has always worked will not necessarily always work going forward. So, I think people have to keep an open mind. But one element is of course recognizing that the capital structure of this group going forward will be one of the ways in which one can maintain value or return even more value to shareholders.

Second issue is of course we're seeing quite a lot of growth in this company, but a bulk of it is now happening outside South Africa. And you always want to be structured in a manner that can take full advantage of the growth. And when I say capital structure here, I'm talking in a broad sense of the word including financial issues and what your balance sheet looks like and how efficient it is and so on.

So, it's really saying, we're keeping an open mind to say how do we continue to achieve that growth, but also achieve it in a capital structure that is as efficient as we possibly can make it, both in people, both in external and international input and on the balance sheet. And there are no firm decisions on that, that's a progress that the board and management will continue to engage in.
Nazir, do you want to answer the question on the deterioration in margin if MTR disappears?

I think the question was if we're faced with a situation where we would not continue growing on-net traffic. I think if on-net traffic stabilizes at the level that we currently see, we ought not to see a dilution in traffic. I think the bigger danger really is competitors following an all-net strategy like Nigeria et cetera, which would force us to do the same. And therefore we'd end up in a situation where we move some of the traffic backwards. That I think is potentially a bigger deterrent.

The things we're doing and Karel and his team I'm very aware of as well as in Nigeria where we potentially are mostly exposed is to follow very segmented value propositions which will make sure that we provide more value to the existing base to stay on our network as opposed to move off onto other networks. So that's really the key driving force of how we would like to manage that particular issue.

I think on the margin story overall, however, I think we take a more holistic view. We've talked about a number of initiatives that we're putting into play not only to deal with a risk around margin dilution because of a change in the interconnect or on-net, off-net traffic mix. But it could come through just purely from pricing pressure that we see in every market. So, you know we've launched a number of different programs, whether they come through from infrastructure sharing. We did a fairly significant analysis or an exercise covering most of our large operations in the portfolio, which is based on an ABC type analysis and that's set up with a view to actually reducing and optimizing the cost base. We've got a lot of outsourcing that Sifiso talked about, outsourcing on the maintenance side, managed services et cetera. If you unpack all of these I think they are directed at one not only to try and generate incremental margin, but also protecting the potential dilution of margin as a result of tariff pressure or from the interconnect side as well.
Okay. Shall we take maybe two more questions and then we can close.

Tuma Johan from Renaissance. Well done on your results. And if I look at your Ghana CapEx guidance, 1.2 billion it seems quite low compared to 2010 actual. Do I read into that the savings due to TowerCo Ghana or how do I approach that number?
Do you want to answer the question on the – Sifiso, do you want to talk about the Ghana CapEx number as to why it would be lower than last year?

Last year's investment in Ghana was quite significant. In the way that we did the budget this year we had not taken the outsourcing process into consideration. It was just the actual requirements of the operation. But the last two years was quite significant, the CapEx that was put in.
And I think there is also some CapEx that didn't completely put in that will be flow...
There was a large carryover from '09 to 2010.
Yeah. Okay. Can we have the last question or one but last it looks like, yeah. So, the question seems to have vanished. Well, there is no last question.

Okay, well, once again I'd just like to thank everybody and a special thank you to the chairman and our board and once again for his very kind and generous words. The last 10 years was a huge team effort. One gets all the accolades, but really, the accolades really belong to the team and one was just honored to serve. Thank you very much. Thanks.
